The Street expects 2017 earnings to rise 18%, which represents an upward revision. Q4 results will be released Feb. 21.Procter & Gamble (PG), another Dow component, advanced 1.21 to 85.22 in brisk volume. The megacap retook its 50-day and 200-day lines. Procter & Gamble is working on a flat base but has some work to do on the right side of its pattern. The base is first stage.In the S&P 500, superregional bank Comerica (CMA) took the hardest hit, gapping down 3.83 to 66.09. Volume was heavy. The company reported quarterly results, topping the earnings target by about 14%. Revenue was lower than expected.IBD'S TAKE: Don't ignore tobacco stocks. Two have outperformed the major indexes for three years in a row.Morgan Stanley (MS) also reported. The money center beat the Street's consensus estimate by about 25%. But the stock dropped 1.24 to 42.58.Other banks reporting this week include Citigroup (C), Goldman Sachs (GS), U.S. Bancorp (USB) and Northern Trust (NTRS), which all report Wednesday. All four were down in midday trade Tuesday.On Thursday, KeyCorp (KEY), SunTrust Banks (STI) and Home BancShares (HOMB) will report. These bank stocks also were down Tuesday.The banks were among the top performers since Election Day but appear to be undergoing some profit-taking. President-elect Donald Trump's negative comments about the strong dollar and the House GOP border-adjustment tax hit financials.Oil prices rose as Saudi Arabia affirmed its previous pledge to cut output. The U.S. oil explorers group rose on the news, but much of the group action was tied to acquisitions.Texas-based Clayton Williams Energy (CWEI) gapped up 37% in monster volume. On Monday, Noble Energy (NBL) announced it would acquire Clayton. Noble was up 7%.Sanchez Energy (SN) added 16% after jumping 29% Friday. On Thursday, Anadarko Petroleum (APC) announced it would sell its Eagleford shale assets to a joint venture that includes Sanchez Energy.RELATED:Trump's Doubts On GOP Tax Plan Help Sink Banks; Morgan Stanley TopsBritish American Tobacco, Reynolds American Agree On $49 Billion MergerMay Pledges U.K. Parliament Vote On Leaving EU Single Market; Pound SoarsNoble Pays $2.7 Billion For Clayton Williams In Permian Basin DealExxon Doubles Stake In Permian BasinArista Dives 9% On Setback in Cisco Legal Battle

Stocks fell at Tuesday's open and remained lower through the day as comments made in London and New York took a toll on the day's trade.The Nasdaq dropped 0.6%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 slipped 0.3% apiece.  Small caps took harder hits than the overall market, leaving the Russell 2000 down 1.4%.U.S. traders took some cues from London, where stocks dropped hard after Prime Minister Theresa May announced Britain would seek to renegotiate its trade agreements outside the European Union's single-market trade protocol.  The statement of fortified independence sent the pound to its biggest gain since 2008, while London's FTSE 100 equity index shed 1.5%. The CAC 40 in Paris slid 0.5%, while Frankfurt's DAX kept to a 0.1% decline.In afternoon trade, 141 of IBD's 197 industry groups moved lower. Superregional banks fell furthest, trading lower after President-elect Donald Trump signaled opposition to a key piece of the GOP's tax strategy.Comerica (CMA) was hardest hit in the group, down 7%. The Dallas-based bank reported fourth-quarter earnings above analyst targets. The stock had been holding steady just below a Jan. 5 high, but dropped to test support at its 10-week moving average. Regions Financial (RF) and SVB Financial Group (SIVB) fell more than 5% each.IBD 50 stock Arista Networks (ANET) led the computer networking group to the day's second-worst loss among industries.  Shares fell 12% in huge trade after the U.S. Customs and Border Patrol agency said it would reinstate an import ban on Arista switches pending further review. The tumble broke support at the stock's 10-week moving average in heavy trade and erased effectively all of its gain since clearing a flat base in November. Both moves are sell signals.Some of the day's strongest moves came from gold miners, as a pullback in the dollar helped boost gold prices more than 1%. A long list of miners — including Anglogold Ashanti (AU), Sibanye Gold (SBGL) and IamGold (IAG) — gained more than 2%.Noble Energy (NBL) topped the S&P 500, rallying 7% after agreeing to buy Clayton Williams Energy (CWEI) in a $2.7 billion deal. The deal gives Noble leases to 120,000 net acres in a key region of West Texas' prolific Permian Basin shale play, as well as a number of pipelines serving that region.  Noble is holding support in the fifth week of a flat consolidation. Clayton Williams shares spiked 40%, putting the stock just below its May 2014 high.After the close, investors have an eye on earnings reports due out from Netflix (NFLX) and chip equipment maker ASML  Holding (ASML).Also after the close, San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams is scheduled to speak at 6 p.m. ET.RELATED:Goldman, Citi, Retail Brokerages; Investing Action PlanBank Stock Losses Intensify After Trump Rips GOP Tax Plan

Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS), Morgan Stanley (MS) — the latter of which topped Q4 forecasts Tuesday morning — and other banks fell after President-elect Donald Trump signaled opposition to a key piece of the GOP's tax strategy, in an interview with the Wall Street Journal, threatening hopes for anticipated tax cuts.The slide comes as investors wait for more clarity on what Trump's plans might actually look like after they get batted around in Congress. Such policy details, Vining Sparks analyst Marty Mosby noted, might not begin to surface until the second half of the year."You're getting more disconnect between what different Republicans want," he said.Lower bond yields also weighed Tuesday, and U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May's speech indicating a so-called "hard Brexit" to separate the country from the EU added to uncertainty over London's future as a banking hub.Even as Morgan Stanley solidly beat analyst expectations on the top and bottom line, the outlook for the industry has continued to overshadow its actual results."These earnings are trivial in relation to the perception that's driving the stocks right now," Mosby said.Shares of Morgan Stanley closed down 3.8% to 42.15 on the stock market today. Goldman Sachs and Citigroup (C), which report Wednesday, were down 3.5% and 2.1%, respectively. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America, which reported earnings last week, fell 3.6% and 4.2%. Wells Fargo (WFC), which also reported last week and plans to more than double its branch closures this year, fell 2.8%.Bank stocks initially took off after the election on hopes the incoming administration and GOP-controlled Congress will cut regulations, grow the economy and create a higher-interest-rate environment. But the sector began to level off last month as the rise in bond yields have slowed.JPMorgan, Citigroup and Wells Fargo shares are approaching their fast-rising 50-day lines for the first time in months, as the 10-year Treasury yield threatens to close below that key level. Superregional bank Comerica (CMA), which also reported better-than-expected earnings early Tuesday, tumbled 6.5% as it tested its 50-day line.Analysts have said the sector could fall more amid uncertainty over how new policy details shake out. The dollar has strengthened on expectations that a stronger economy could lead to higher interest rates, which help banks' finances.IBD'S TAKE: Banks are likely to close more branches as they try to cut costs and as more people manage their finances over their phones. Other forms of technology, like blockchain, could help the industry save billions.Morgan Stanley's Q4 earnings per share surged 88% to 81 cents, above estimates for 65 cents, while revenue rose 15% to $9.02 billion, beating forecasts for $8.47 billion.Revenue for the bank's institutional securities segment rose 35%, helped by strength in trading and M&A. Sales in the bank's important wealth management division rose 6%.However, equity underwriting revenue fell 36%, and compensation expenses rose 10%."We reported solid results in Sales & Trading and Advisory, and record revenues in Wealth Management, while managing expenses prudently," CEO James Gorman said in the company's earnings release. "We are optimistic about opportunities in 2017 and beyond and remain focused on serving our clients and achieving our strategic objectives."RELATED:Banks Among Few S&P 500 Beneficiaries As Higher Rates LoomAs The Dow Nears 20K, These 5 Stocks Have Led The Way

Baird named Tesla (TSLA) a top pick in 2017, Deutsche Bank upgraded China Lodging Group (HTHT), and Mizuho initiated coverage on Gamestop (GME) with a buy rating.Baird Equity Research named the electric car maker a top stock pick for 2017. Automotive analyst Ben Kallo reiterated an outperform rating and price target of 338. "We think the ramp of Tesla Energy and Model 3 production could exceed expectations during 2017, and believe the opportunity is not currently reflected in share prices," Kallo said in a report.Tesla stock rose as high as 217.50 soon after the market open, but erased all those gains and closed 0.5% lower at 213.69 on the stock market today. Tesla this week moved above its 200-day moving average for the first time in four months.Deutsche Bank upgraded China Lodging Group to buy with a price target of 60.U.S.-listed shares of China Lodging jumped 6% to close at 51.84. The stock jumped 66% in 2016, but has slipped from a high of 53.36 set on Dec. 13.Mizuho initiated coverage on Gamestop with a buy rating and PT of 35, after Standpoint research on Thursday started the stock at buy and PT of 34.Gamestop dipped 0.3% to end at 25.26, with shares about flat for 2016.Mizuho also initiated Zynga (ZNGA) at buy with a PT of 3.50. Shares slipped 1% to 2.57 Friday.In other analyst moves, Standpoint Research Thursday upgraded Newmont Mining (NEM) to buy with a PT of 42. Shares fell 3% Friday after soaring 7.6% Thursday to 35.27, as gold prices rallied this week.Piper Jaffray raised Comerica's (CMA) PT to 71 from 68; shares in the super regional bank rose 0.3% to 68.11.Northland Capital markets initiated coverage of biotech Intrexon (XON) with an outperform rating and PT of 40. Shares dropped 2.5% to 24.30.

Your personal finance plan in 2017 will be like baking a cake. All you'll need is the right recipe. Whether you're investing in stocks, bonds, ETFs or mutual funds in a 401(k) retirement account, now's the time to check to make sure you have the right ingredients at hand.For Phil Orlando, chief equity strategist at Federated Investors, the recipe involves six ingredients: overweight U.S. stocks in general; underweight 10-year Treasury bonds; and overweight financial services stocks, U.S. small-cap stocks, energy stocks and industrial companies' stocks.Orlando's colleague, Steve Chiavarone, associate manager of $414 million Federated Global Allocation Fund (FSTBX), cites holdings which illustrate that recipe. Among them, Apple (AAPL) could see higher profits if corporate taxes are lowered as President-elect Trump wants. It could also boost stock dividends or buybacks and spend more to develop new products with repatriated cash under Trump's tax proposal. "Still, Trump has issues with parts of the tech industry, so Apple's may be a more mixed picture," Chiavarone said.In addition, a more lenient regulatory environment for banks would convert JPMorgan (JPM) from a something akin to a regulated utility back into a growth stock, Chiavarone says. Oilfield services giant Halliburton (HAL) should get more mileage out of its run, fueled by rising energy prices, he adds. And construction aggregates producer Martin Marietta (MLM) is poised to benefit from a boom in infrastructure projects.IBD'S TAKE: Martin Marietta is No. 2 in IBD's Building-Cement/Concrete-Aggregates industry group. To see how the company's growth metrics — like its strong 83 IBD Composite Rating and very strong 96 EPS (earnings per share) Rating stack up against its rivals, visit IBD Stock Checkup.To Orlando and Chiavarone, the 2017 recipe aims to take advantage of several macroeconomic forces now in play.In financials, $1.2 billion Third Avenue Value (TAVFX) lead manager Chip Rewey says U.S. regional banks are likely to benefit from rate hikes and scaled-back regulation. Their valuations are also relatively low "since people have shunned them since the financial crisis."Banks he likes include top holdings Bank of New York Mellon (BK), Comerica (CMA), PNC Financial (PNC) and Keycorp (KEY). All have strong Composite Ratings from IBD in the 80s or 90s.Among other stocks, he said home-builder "Lennar (LEN) is a new position for Value Fund because housing should do well." Its balance sheet is improving, it is reducing debt and it is trimming its land bank.He also recently bought shares in Johnson Controls (JCI). Some investors still think of it as a maker of automotive seating, a field it has exited. "Its hidden gem is its car batteries," Rewey said. "They are a leader in lead acid batteries and in start-stop batteries. And they, not Tesla (TSLA), are the leader in lithium ion car batteries."In addition, Rewey likes biotech Amgen (AMGN), a relative newcomer to the portfolio, largely "because the market is ignoring its strong pipeline."And true to his value orientation, Rewey likes apparel company Ralph Lauren (RL). Earnings per share growth has declined eight straight quarters. The stock's Comp Rating is a dismal 7. "But Rewey likes CEO Stefan Larsson's turnaround credentials. "We think it's a great opportunity," Rewey said.Lee DeLorenzo, president of United Asset Strategies in Garden City, N.Y., says workers should try to take advantage of the same apparent forces in their 401(k) accounts. At the same time, they should cut their interest-rate risk by shifting 5% to 10% of their weighting in traditional bond funds to stable value funds or flexible, go-anywhere bond funds.She advises increasing exposure to small- and midcap stocks and stock funds. Plan members who can stomach risk, she says, should boost their weightings in financials and energy.Rich Weiss, a senior portfolio manager on a team that oversees 20 American Century target-date, target-risk and asset-allocation funds, says 401(k) plan members should also look at whether the year-end spurt in stock prices threw their target asset allocations out of whack. Does your mix of stocks, large and small, U.S. and foreign, specific geographies and selected sectors, still jibe with your overall financial plan? Your risk tolerance? Your financial goals?If something has grown too big, take profits to rebalance. Keep the proceeds inside your account to avoid an early withdrawal.Plan members who'd rather not make their own investment decisions should leave the heavy lifting to target-date and target-risk funds within their accounts, he says. If you do want to forge your own investment decisions, you can look for ideas at the asset allocations of target date and target risk portfolios that match your situation. "But doing that may be more expensive and complex than simply purchasing an appropriate target-date fund," Weiss added.If your 401(k) does not offer target-date or target-risk funds? Consider investing that same money instead in such a fund inside an IRA, where your investment choices are almost unlimited.In addition, Weiss says, if your 401(k) offers a Roth option, use it if you are young and if your tax bracket will stay the same or rise after you retire. Meanwhile, contributions are not tax deductible. But earnings grow tax-deferred. And withdrawals normally will be tax-free, unlike withdrawals from a regular 401(k) or IRA.Suppose you share the Orlando-Chiavarone vision of what 2017 is to bring. How do you act on it?One approach would be to boost the assets, sectors and geographies that they expect to thrive by 10% in your portfolio. Trim from assets like long Treasuries and emerging-markets stocks. You can tweak those numbers up or down, depending on factors such as your time horizon, risk tolerance, long-term goals and any near-term need for cash.If you're an aggressive investor in your 30s, for instance, you might want to boost your U.S. small caps by 11% or 12%.In any case, first form your 2017 financial action plan, either with your financial advisor or on your own. Then look for securities that can bring that plan to life. It's not all that hard. In fact, reflecting holiday cheer, DeLorenzo said, "The execution of these changes is as easy as baking a cake."RELATED:2017 Personal Finance Action Plan & 2016 Stock Market ReviewHot Stocks That Made Craig Hodges A Top 2016 Mutual Fund ManagerWhere Mutual Fund Pros See Big Stock Gains In 2017Here's How To Decide Which Retirement Accounts To Fund First

Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena will probably fail to lure sufficient demand for a 5 billion-euro ($5.2 billion) capital raise, said people with knowledge of the matter, making a state rescue likely.Liquidity has been drying up, the bank said in a filing Wednesday amid mounting concern about the lender's viability. Shares in the troubled lender fell 12 percent to 16.30 euros in Milan. The stock has declined 87 percent this year, trimming the bank's market value to about 478 million euros.The bank's board is meeting in Siena on Wednesday to review the latest numbers on investor orders. Qatar's sovereign-wealth fund, which had considered an investment, hasn't yet committed to buying shares, while a second debt-for-equity swap has raised about 500 million euros through Tuesday, before today's expiry of the offer, people with knowledge of the matter have said.Other institutions that were considering buying shares have indicated that they would put funds in the troubled bank only if it's able to raise 2 billion euros from the swap and 1 billion euros from cornerstone investors, according to the people."So far reports about Monte Paschi's efforts to find private capital are quite discouraging -- it seems as if a government intervention comes closer by the day," Par Magnusson, a strategist at Swedbank, wrote in a report Wednesday. A government intervention "will punish equity and junior bond holders, and that is a major concern in itself."In a supplement to the offer information document, the bank said its liquidity, which stood at 10.6 billion euros as of Dec. 16, may run out more quickly than previously expected. Commenting on risks under rules defined by the Bank of Italy, Paschi said it may run out of liquidity after four months, rather than 11 months forecast in last week's supplement.The lender's subordinated bond risk rose to a record. Its 500 million euros of junior notes due in March 2019 fell 6 cents on the euro to an all-time low of 44 cents, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Credit swaps insuring the bank's junior bonds for five years now imply a 70 percent chance of default, data compiled by CMA show.The Italian government late Monday moved closer to a potential rescue of lenders, including Monte Paschi, by seeking permission from parliament to increase the nation's public debt by as much as 20 billion euros. The plan is aimed at providing a backstop to the banking system "through public guarantees in order to restore their short- and medium-term lending ability," Finance Minister Pier Carlo Padoan said following a cabinet meeting Monday night.Monte Paschi's plan to raise 5 billion euros has three interlocking pieces: a debt-for-equity swap, a stock offering and the disposal of soured loans. The capital being raised would be used to cover the bank for losses it would book in selling the bad debt. If the sale fails, the conversions of debt to equity would be nullified.Monte Paschi expanded and extended its debt-for-equity swap last week. In the previous offer, bondholders had already agreed to exchange about 1.02 billion euros for shares.If government funds are used in the bank's recapitalization, its bondholders will probably have to take losses under European burden-sharing rules. The cabinet is considering a so-called precautionary recapitalization that may reduce the potential losses. A meeting is scheduled Friday to determine the details, a government official said.Here is a summary of other Italian lenders facing pressure to shore up their finances and get rid of soured debt on their books.Banca Carige: The European Central Bank instructed the Genoa-based lender to step up efforts to reduce sour debt on its balance sheet, giving it until Feb. 28 to present a more aggressive proposal. The existing plan calls for cutting the total to 19.9 percent by 2020 from 27.8 percent in 2015. The bank, which is struggling to restore investor confidence after revising its 2012 and first-half 2013 accounts, posted a loss in the third quarter on falling revenue and higher provisions for bad loans.Banca Popolare di Vicenza/Veneto Banca: The rescued Italian lenders in merger talks may need as much as 2.5 billion euros of fresh capital to fulfill requests from the ECB, people with knowledge of the matter have said. The ECB said the pair should reduce bad loans by as much as 4 billion euros, increase liquidity buffers and make additional provisions for ongoing litigation, the people said. Atlante, the state-orchestrated fund which took over the banks earlier this year, on Wednesday said it will invest 938 million euros in further stock sales by the banks.Four "Good Banks" : The four small domestic lenders rescued from collapse last year must be sold to comply with European regulators' requests. Executives obtained an extension of June's deadline as they struggle to reach a deal. Unione di Banche Italiane is in talks to buy three of the four regional banks. The Bank of Italy may seek additional contributions from lenders to bolster the country's resolution fund if the sale doesn't generate enough cash to repay creditors, people with knowledge of the matter have said.

Drugmaker Actavis faces fines for raising the cost of hydrocortisone tablets by more than 12,000%, British antitrust regulators said Friday as they continued a crackdown on excessive pricing in the pharmaceutical industry.The division of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries (TEVA) "broke competition law by charging excessive and unfair prices in the U.K.," the Competition and Markets Authority said in a statement. In one example, The company raised the price of the 10 milligram packs from roughly 88 cents to $110 in U.S. currency. Teva, which acquired Actavis for $40.5 billion from Allergan (AGN) earlier this year, said it will "defend the allegations.""This is a lifesaving drug relied on by thousands of patients, which the (U.K.'s National Health Service, or NHS) has no choice but to continue purchasing," said Andrew Groves, CMA senior responsible officer. "We allege that the company has taken advantage of this situation and the removal of the drug from price regulation, leaving the NHS — and ultimately the taxpayer — footing the bill for the substantial price rises."The CMA sent Actavis a statement of objections laying out its concerns amid a wider crackdown on unfair drug pricing. On Dec. 7, the CMA fined Pfizer (PFE) and Flynn Pharma a record amount for abusing their dominant position by charging unfair prices for unbranded versions of the Epanutin anti-epilepsy drug.The regulator fined Pfizer roughly $105.2 million and Flynn Pharma $6.5 million after they increased prices by as much as 2,600% in September 2012. The price increases occurred after Pfizer transferred distribution rights to Flynn, which sold the medicine by its generic name, phenytoin sodium.Teva, which is already in the process of selling Actavis's U.K. operations to Intas Pharmaceuticals Ltd., said the CMA probe raises broader questions about the regulation of generic medications.Although the pricing of the Actavis product "under investigation was never under Teva's effective control, Teva believes that intervention by the CMA in prices for generic medicines raises serious policy concerns regarding the roles of both the CMA and the Department of Health," Teva said. "Generic medicines continue to be an affordable alternative to branded therapies."A statement of objections can often lead to fines or orders to change business practices. The regulator has the power to fine companies found to have abused a dominant market position up to 10% of their annual revenue.Hydrocortisone tablets are used as the primary replacement therapy for people whose adrenal glands do not produce sufficient amounts of natural steroid hormones, resulting in conditions such as Addison's disease. The tablets are also used to treat conditions such as arthritis, blood, hormone and immune system disorders, skin and eye conditions, breathing problems, cancer, and severe allergies.Actavis also increased the price of 20 milligram hydrocortisone tablets by nearly 9,500%, resulting in charges to the NHS of $128.32 per pack by March 2016, the CMA said. The NHS had previously paid the equivalent of $1.34 per pack.Before April 2008, the NHS spent about 522,000 pounds a year on hydrocortisone tablets. By 2015, NHS spend on the tablets had risen to $87.4 million a year.Steep price hikes have put a string of drugmakers under the microscope in the U.S. with companies like Mylan (MYL) and Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (VRX). bearing the brunt of the public outrage. President-elect Donald Trump, who had been cited as a boon to free-market health care, also declared himself an opponent of high drug prices in an interview with Time magazine.

Super-regional banks are plenty big, but not too big to fail. The industry has been a relatively sweet spot for investors recently, and it may be sweeter still under President Donald Trump. Despite a slow-growth economic environment, the increasing likelihood of a resumption in Federal Reserve rate hikes, the prospect of some regulatory relief for banks — especially those that don't pose systemic…

Stocks held on to mild gains with an hour remaining in Wednesday's relatively mild trading session ahead of tonight's final presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. Banks, e-commerce, energy and commodity plays led the upside.Meanwhile, Tesla Motors (TSLA) posted its biggest gain in two weeks, rolling 3% higher to 204.17 in fast turnover. CEO Elon Musk tweeted followers that a news conference would take place at 5 p.m. Pacific Time. Company observers are speculating a new product unveiling, such as an electric motorcycle, a new Roadster, or a new version of the upcoming Model 3 entry-level sedan.IBD'S TAKE: Tesla Motors is still consolidating and trading well below its 52-week highs. So a potential breakout is still potentially weeks away. To find leading stocks that are clearing proper buy points and making money for investors right now, view the IBD 50 list of elite fast-growing companies.The S&P 500 rose 0.3%, holding near its session highs. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.4% while the Russell 2000 outperformed, up nearly 0.6%.The Nasdaq composite was 0.1% higher, hurt by a sharp 6% drop in Intel (INTC) shares following Q3 results late Wednesday. Watch to see if Intel can rebound back to and eventually above its rising 50-day moving average.Banking shares continued to gain steam.In the super regional bank industry group, Comerica (CMA) rallied more than 3% to 51.79. Volume was running double its usual level. The Dallas-based bank is rising sharply after posting a 24% jump in third-quarter profit to 92 cents a share, the biggest EPS increase in seven quarters. Revenue climbed 6% vs. year-ago levels for the second straight quarter.Comerica has now rallied nearly 11% past a 46.71 buy point in a 12-week cup with handle. The buy point comes from adding 10 cents to the intraday high of the Aug. 8 session, when the stock began forming the tight handle in mostly thin trade. The handle provides the last shakeout of uncommitted shareholders, cleaning the decks for a potential breakout to new highs when strong institutional demand for shares arrives.Comerica's group peer Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) also rose more than 3%, jumping off its rising 50-day moving average in heavy trading to 20.63. The stock had cleared a 20.37 handle buy point on a nine-month cup base on Sept. 14 and rose mildly before retreating below that price level. Now the stock is trying a second breakout and is in buy range.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) added 1% to 68.42, standing just outside the 5% permissible buy range from a recent cup-with-handle breakout at 65.08.Elsewhere in the stock market today, online e-commerce firms held firm. Alibaba (BABA) rose for a third session in a row, up 0.8% to 104.19. The stock is still in buy range after a first test of the 50-day moving average near 100. The first and second rebounds off the 50-day or 10-week line offer a chance for investors to buy shares correctly.Alibaba is now up 22% from an 85.10 entry on a long cup-with-handle base that it cleared on Aug. 9, initially in light volume. But then volume surged the next few days as the breakout took hold.GrubHub (GRUB) slipped 0.2% to 42.15, yet is holding above its 50-day moving average. The online restaurant food pick-up and delivery ordering service triggered a buy signal near 40.50 on Oct. 13 as shares rebounded sharply back above the 50-day line in heavy volume.GrubHub, an IBD Leaderboard stock, has notched one quarter of accelerating EPS growth as earnings grew 11% in the first quarter of this year, then 35% in Q2.Wall Street expects Q3 profit growth to speed up even more, up 46% to 19 cents a share.Over the past four quarters, GrubHub's sales have risen 38%, 36%, 27% and 37%. The stock scores a top-notch A SMR (Sales + Margins + Return on equity) from IBD Stock Checkup.In economic news, the Federal Reserve's latest beige book survey of regional economies across the country was released at 2 p.m. ET. In the summary, the Fed noted most districts indicated a "modest or moderate pace of expansion" during the reporting period from late August to early October. The pace of growth improved in the St. Louis, Kansas City and Dallas districts.RELATED:What Will Tesla Motors Unveil Wednesday Evening?What Kind Of Base Did Goldman Sachs Form?What To Do When Volume On The Breakout Is Initially LightWhen Did JPMorgan Chase Shares Break Out?

Banks retreated Thursday, testing buy points as Treasury yields fell ahead of earnings from Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) out Friday.Treasury yields were down Thursday after a weaker-than-expected trade report out of China sent investors toward government bonds and other safe assets. Investors have bid financials in recent weeks on the prospect of Federal Reserve rate hikes and the recent rise of long-term yields around the world. JPMorgan fell 0.6% to 67.74 on the stock market today after dropping as low as 66.82, just above the 50-day line. The stock is still in range from a buy point of 65.08, cleared in early August.JPMorgan is expected to report a 17% drop in third-quarter earnings but revenue is seen rising 2% to $23.988 billion when it announces quarterly results Friday.Citigroup shares dipped 0.5% to 48.47 after sinking intraday to 47.54, below a recent 48.24 buy point. Analysts see Citi's Q3 EPS falling 15% on Friday to $1.15, with revenue down 6% to $17.344 billion. Wells Fargo shares slid 1.3% to 44.75 well below its 50-day and 200-day lines. The bank has its own issues after a Consumer Financial Protection Bureau review found employees may have opened more than 2 million accounts and credit cards without consumers' permission. Late Wednesday, Wells said CEO John Stumpf stepped down, effective immediately, replaced by President and COO Tim Sloan.Bank of America (BAC) is slated to report results Monday, Goldman Sachs (GS) Tuesday, and Morgan Stanley (MS) on Wednesday. BofA shares fell 1.25%, continuing a recent slide after peeking into buy range on Monday. Goldman lost 1.1% and Morgan Stanley 0.6%.IBD'S TAKE: U.K.'s Brexit, bad loans at Italian banks and legal troubles from Germany's Deutsche Bank have opened the European market to U.S. banks. Regional banks, more directly dependent of lending than global Wall Street banks, were also under pressure Thursday.Comerica (CMA) shares fell 1.4% to 47.91, still in buy range, with a 46.40 buy point, out of a cup with handle base but falling toward its 50-day line.SunTrust Banks (STI) shares tumbled 2.1% to 44.76 falling toward its 50-day line but still in buy range, above its buy point of 44.42, after consolidating out of a flat base.Regions Financial (RF) stock fell 2.8% to 9.95, finding support at its 50-day line and off session lows of 9.78, but below its buy point of 10.10.RELATED:Bank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain Embrace

Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) have broken out this week on growing Federal Reserve rate-hike speculation and relief over Deutsche Bank (DB).After AFP reported that Deutsche Bank could settle a mortgage-securities case for far less than the Justice Department asked for, potentially warding off a bigger shock to the global banking industry, Bank of America and Citigroup on Friday bounced off their 50-day lines. Meanwhile, Fed officials' comments and recent economic data have reinforced expectations for central bank tightening by the end of the year.Banks and bank stocks should do well if the Fed raises rates because it allow them to increase the spread between its lending rates and borrowing costs. Banks' net interest margins have been squeezed in recent years.JPMorgan Chase (JPM), meanwhile, also rebounded off its 50-day. JPMorgan broke out in early August from a handle in a consolidation and remains within range of the 66.58 buy point. JPMorgan rose 1.6% to 67.69 Wednesday.Citigroup climbed 1.9% to 48.65 in the stock market today, hitting its best levels since early January. Citigroup cleared a 48.28 buy point in an 11-month consolidation.Bank of America advanced 2.% to 16.11. BofA is 4.9% above its 50-day line, still within the chase zone. Ideally, for a stock to be within buy range, it should be no more than 5% above the 50-day line.Wells Fargo rose 2.8%, but from a two-and-a-half-year low. Wells Fargo is still reeling from the cross-selling scandal.IBD'S TAKE: The Banks-Money Center industry group, which includes the big banks, moves in tandem with the Federal Reserve's announcements on interest rates. To learn more about top industry groups and taking profits quickly rapid changes in the market, see this story about Swing Trading strategies. Meanwhile, some super-regional banks also have broken out. SunTrust Banks (STI) broke past a 44.71 buy point of a consolidation pattern begun in late May on Tuesday. On Wednesday, SunTrust rose 2.2% to 45.73, still in range. SunTrust had found resistance several times just above 44 in recent months.Meanwhile, Comerica (CMA) rose 2.8% to 49.21 Wednesday, extended from buy range but still performing solidly.Wednesday's bank stock gains come as ADP reported that companies added 154,000 jobs in September, short of estimates for 170,000 but still solid. Meanwhile, the ISM nonmanufacturing index shot up to an 11-month high last month. On Monday, ISM's manufacturing index signaled a return to factory expansion.RELATED:New High Analysis: Session Yields Slew Of Financial BreakoutsU.S. Banking Giants Gain As Deutsche Bank, European Financials TeeterBank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain EmbraceJPMorgan, Goldman, Citi Waver As Rates To Stay Lower For Longer

Dancing to the Federal Reserve's familiar rate-hike-is-coming tune in August, the major stock market indexes did little more than tread water near multiyear if not all-time highs.A pullback by defensive sectors largely offset an advance by cyclical sectors as the S&P 500 inched up 0.14%. U.S. diversified stock mutual funds edged ahead 0.48%, according to Lipper Inc.General domestic taxable bond funds rose 0.74% to be up 8.53% for the year.At an economic symposium in Jackson Hole, Wyo., in late August, Fed Chair Janet Yellen and other Fed officials said the economy is strong enough for a rate hike.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Six-Month Leaders"The fact that the market saw an opportunity for a rate increase at the Sept. 21 (Fed) meeting was an indication that the U.S. economy was actually moving in the right direction," said Omar Aguilar, chief investment officer, equities at Charles Schwab Investment Management. "So the market reacted to that."Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Category PerformanceThat reaction took the form of a rotation out of high-dividend stocks and stable sectors into more economically cyclical sectors, Aguilar said. Investors pulled money out of utilities, consumer staples and telecom, he added. They shifted much of it into technology, health care, consumer discretionary and financials.Sector funds reflected some of that. Financial services funds gained 4.25% last month on average. Tech funds gained 2.33%. Health/biotech and consumer-goods funds lost ground.The mood shifted again early this month when the Bureau of Labor Statistics revised the count of its July jobs gains upward to 275,000, but reported August jobs gains of only 151,000. That was less than the 180,000 jobs forecast by economists polled by Reuters. The relatively weak employment growth increased the odds that the Fed would delay its rate hike until November or even December, and the stock market rallied modestly and rotated back toward dividend stocks."There isn't a lot of market leadership now," Aguilar said last week. "Bottom line: We're going to have to wait until the Fed's September meeting to know what comes next."IBD's TAKE: How will investors react once the Fed finally hikes rates? Understanding the stock market's prevailing trend is a key factor when you are choosing between growth and defensive stock buys. For pointers, visit IBD University.Chip Rewey, lead manager of Third Avenue's $1.2 billion Value (TVFVX) and $317 million Small Cap Value (TVSVX) funds, said "the market is confused by the Fed, the way Charlie Brown is confused by Lucy."Rewey added that whenever the Fed does raise rates, sustained, aggressive hikes are unlikely. "Still, why allocate (money) to yield-oriented sectors when you see a raise coming off generational low rates?" he asked.Instead, Rewey has added to stocks that should not be hurt by a hike. He recently increased his stake in Johnson Controls (JCI), which makes building-efficiency systems and just completed its combination with Tyco, which makes fire and security systems."We like the merger with Tyco," Rewey said. "There's a lot of misunderstanding about what type of company Johnson is. Many people still think of it as an auto company (because of its history as a maker of car seats and interiors). But the majority post-Tyco merger is a building services company."Rewey also added to Amgen (AMGN), which has a dividend yield of 2.3%. "We saw it as a leading pharmaceuticals (company) that had been caught in the generic fears about (drugmakers because of political calls for intervention over pricing)."Rewey bought shares under 150. They're now trading near 170. "At that price, we're getting its pipeline for free," he said. The company has 31 potential treatments in preclinical and clinical targets development, including 12 in phase three tests, which are closer to market. Another nine biosimilars are in development, including three in later stages, nearing the point where they might go on sale.Rewey also likes Comerica (CMA), a bank with most of its operations in Michigan, Texas, California, Arizona and Florida. "It's trading around 1.1 times tangible book value," he said. "We think it's undervalued. They're cutting costs. If rates and loan growth go up, their return on equity will go up."And Rewey likes media giant CBS (CBS), which is controlled by Sumner Redstone through National Amusements, which also controls Viacom (VIA). Some family members and company executives have been jockeying for power over the company once Redstone ceases to exercise control."Investor overreaction to the noise over Viacom has weighed on the value of CBS stock," Rewey said. "They are taking an advertising driven model and taking it to more fee-driven (which should generate revenue and earnings that are more visible and stable). They should be almost 60% fee-driven by 2018 once they spin out their radio business. And they're in a stock buyback program. And we like the management team, led by Les Moonves."James Abate, chief investment officer of Centre Funds and manager of its $156 million Select Equity (DHAMX), says it's possible the Fed won't raise rates in the wake of disappointing recent economic data.In this environment, he likes consumer staples names PepsiCo (PEP) and Kimberly Clark (KMB) for their aggressive cost cutting. He likes the outlook for Coach (COH), whose rising sales per employee show that its restructuring is on track, he says. And he likes Facebook (FB) and Amazon (AMZN), whose innovations provide them with a competitive moat.RELATED:The August Jobs Report Was The Weakest Since 2010As Companies Step Up Wage Hikes, Tax Receipts Get A LiftMutual Fund Strategists Like U.S. Stocks, Led By Tech, Health Care In A Sluggish Market

Even as the Federal Reserve signals that tougher standards lie ahead for its annual stress tests, banks like JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C), Bank of America (BAC) and others could still get more generous with their payouts as the tests become more routine, analysts suggest.After the Fed approved 31 of 33 bank capital plans late Wednesday, JPMorgan announced a $10.6 billion buyback, Bank of America OK'd a $5 billion repurchase and a 50% payout increase, and Citigroup unveiled a $8.6 billion buyback and more than tripled its dividend. Morgan Stanley (MS) hiked its dividend 33% and announced a $3.5 billion buyback.The results "highlight the capital strength that enabled the sector to broadly increase payout requests," Fitch Ratings said in a statement Thursday, later adding that banks are "becoming increasingly comfortable with the annual process."As massive as the shareholder returns unveiled Wednesday were, there appears to be room for more among giants like JPMorgan, Citigroup and Bank of America, based on the ratio of dividends and buybacks vs. earnings expected over the next year.Comerica (CMA) and M&T Bank (MTB) lead banks with net payout ratios of 119% each, followed by Morgan Stanley at 105%, according to Credit Suisse. Meanwhile, JPMorgan's is 73%, while the ratio for both Goldman Sachs (GS) and Wells Fargo (WFC) is 65%, Citigroup's is 63%, and Bank of America's is 49%.Shares of Morgan Stanley climbed 3% on the stock market today. JPMorgan added 1.5%. Bank of America and Citigroup rose 0.6%. Goldman Sachs climbed 2.1%.Even before the stress test results came out, analysts have been expecting the banks to get more aggressive with shareholder returns after finally emerging from the aftereffects of the financial crisis.A CLSA note this month said JPMorgan, Citigroup, Bank of America and Wells Fargo are likely to hand out a bigger chunk of profits over the next four years, meaning greater gains for investors who stuck with them through lean times.Portales Partners this month said it expects banks "to get more creative in their capital return requests, as the companies are becoming more familiar with the process" of submitting capital plans for the stress tests, as well as resubmitting them if the Fed has any concerns with risk assessment or whether banks' dividend and buyback plans could overburden their finances if the economy falters.But even as banks push the envelope on capital returns and become more accustomed to the yearly drill of visualizing their state of affairs in an economic crisis, the Fed has warned of potentially stricter capital requirements in future tests."The Fed noted that, despite general progress, banks still need to improve internal controls around various elements of capital planning," Fitch said.

Big banks JPMorgan (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) got through the second and final round of the Federal Reserve's annual stress tests unscathed, resulting in a shareholder-returns bonanza shortly after the test results were announced late Wednesday.But Morgan Stanley's (MS) capital plan only got conditional approval, and U.S. segments of Deutsche Bank (DB) and Santander (SAN) failed once againStill, Morgan Stanley said it will move forward with a 33% quarterly dividend hike to 20 cents and a $3.5 billion buyback. JPMorgan OK'd a $10.6 billion buyback but kept its dividend the same. Bank of America announced a $5 billion repurchase program and a 50% payout increase to 7.5 cents. Citigroup will buy back $8.6 billion in stock and raised its payout to 16 cents from 5 cents.Goldman Sachs (GS) didn't give specifics but said its plan included buybacks and a dividend hike. Wells Fargo (WFC)  kept its capital plans unchanged.Morgan Stanley stock were little changed in pre-market trading on the stock market today after rising late Wednesday JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Citigroup climbed 2.4%, Wells Fargo rose and Goldman Sachs all rose fractionally. Deutsche Bank, which the IMF said "poses the greatest risk to the global financial system," sank nearly 4% while Santander fell 2%.Other banks also announced bigger returns to shareholders.The Fed only gave conditional approval to Morgan Stanley's capital plan, in which it projected how it would perform under difficult economic conditions for this year's stress tests. As a result, Morgan must resubmit its capital plan and address broader concerns from the Fed by Dec. 29. If Morgan can't deliver on those promises, the Fed said, its governors "would expect to object" to the resubmitted plan, potentially hindering Morgan's shareholder returns.While the Fed did not technically object to Morgan Stanley's capital plan, the central bank said the company "exhibited material weaknesses in its capital planning process," including in governance, modeling and other safeguards."These weaknesses warrant further near-term attention but do not undermine the quantitative results of the stress tests for the firm," the Fed said, referring to the portion of the tests that quantifies what banks' capital levels would look like under financial turmoil.The Fed said Deutsche Bank and Santander, both of which also had their plans rejected last year, had tightened up some aspects of their capital planning methodology but still struggled with "material unresolved supervisory issues that critically undermine (the) capital planning process."The results follow a pattern of stress-test one-upmanship between the banks, which have been shoring up capital since the financial crisis, and the Fed, which has tried harder each year to catch the banks off-guard in the scenarios posed in the tests.While the banks that passed can move forward with their dividend and buyback hikes, tougher standards on the horizon could keep payouts restrained this year. Fed Governor Daniel Tarullo warned this month that banks in future tests might have to make a "significant increase" in the assets they set aside to cushion against a potential economic crisis.The final round of results from the stress tests -- known as the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review, or CCAR -- came after all 33 tested banks last week passed the first round of the evaluation, which quantifies how banks' finances would be affected against a barrage of market shocks.The Fed outlined the economic scenarios for both tests at the beginning of the year. In the weeks that followed, the banks submitted their capital plans, which this year forecast how they would do amid 10% unemployment, negative interest rates on short-term U.S. Treasuries -- among the conditions in the Fed's worst-case scenario.The first round of test results can serve as a preview of sorts to the second, in which the Fed actually indicates whether it accepted, rejected or had any reservations with the banks' capital plans. If it does have an issue, banks could have to temper plans to issue buybacks and boost dividends in order to pass.The second round of tests contains both a quantitative element and qualitative element. The quantitative element measures banks post-stress-test capital levels and whether they could sustain any new dividend and buyback plans. The qualitative element evaluates the soundness of the banks' capital plans and how they were developed.Analysts largely had not anticipated major problems with the banks' stress-test results.

Stocks came under selling pressure early yesterday morning as expected, but then did a complete 180 degree turn around closing mostly higher with the Dow up triple digits, piercing the psychologically important 18k level while the S&P surged 13 pts ending the day right on the highs as the rally that people love to hate moves on. Pressure on oil prices worked against stocks in the first moments of trading but investors/traders and the big banks ended up ignoring the news out of Doha in a move that surprised many.Mkts around the world are all celebrating today...taking their cue from the turnaround in US equities....US futures are rocketing higher - currently up 11 pts as we kiss the psychological 2100 level.....but as my friend Scott Redler (@RedDogT3) tells me on twitter this morning"The first kiss us usually meets some opposition, then the romance gets you around the bases" - to which I say - Yes, but it is the first kiss that is the sweetest which makes you want to go back for more.....and more is what it looks like we are gonna get today.....Remember - the mkt is a discounting mechanism....it is looking 4 - 6 months out....the trading today is not about today.....(Just sayin.....) - it is really about what the mkts expect in the fall......and by the looks of it - the mkt is expecting great things...Asian mkts were all higher overnight - Japan which got clobbered on Monday - snapped back and regained 100% of Monday's losses.....as we saw the Yen weaken a bit....a stabilizing oil mkt is also helping to support mkts today....After yesterday's mkt action - it appears that investors are disconnecting from the whims of the oil mkt....at least for now and concentrating on earnings.....European mkts are also enjoying an explosive rally....because why? Earnings and oil......and the sense is that maybe - the whole Mid-East OPEC summit was all hype.....to confuse the conversation.....interesting that the possibility of increased production has caused oil to stabilize and rally a bit from the Monday lows.....Does it feel like something else is going on? FTSE +0.56%, CAC 40 + 1.21%, DAX + 2.22%, EUROSTOXX +1.58%, SPAIN +0.88% and ITALY + 0.57%.Now just a thought or two about yesterday.....and the role that the Deputy Crown Prince is now playing......Look the big story was OIL and POLITICS – Mid East politics – and after two months of all the hype about this pending agreement in a production freeze – traders and the mkts had to deal with the fact that there was no deal – which now sets up the oil mkt for a possible 'free for all'….Keep your eyes on Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman – for he is now the name to know – for it was this 30 yr old son of King Salman who has now turned over the apple cart and merged the commercial considerations of the kingdom with his political stance – a move that is in complete contrast to what was existing policy.......You see for the past 20 yrs – Ali Al-Naimi – the current Saudi oil minister has kept those two issues on separate pages – keeping supply and pricing as the main drivers of any production decisions, always cooperating with the other members – including Iran – no matter what their politics were – in the past to cut production to boost oil prices. The Deputy Crown Prince is not sure he agrees with this policy and so while all the talk has been about how the Saudi's were cooperating with Russia, Venezuela and Qatar – Iran was still the thorn in Prince Mohammed's side….so in a bid to establish himself as an emerging 'force' - as the potential heir to the throne - he nixed the oil deal sending oil mkts into a tailspin on Sunday night/Monday.What is important to understand is that the deputy Crown Prince has now burst onto the global stage since his father became King last year and appears to have every intention of letting the world know. He was appointed the Defense Minister – and is the one responsible for launching the latest military campaign in Yemen while also chairing the country's 'economic planning body' and the council that controls the massive 'state owned' oil company. In a telling interview last week with Bloomberg – the Prince was very clear –"We don't care about oil prices, $30 or $70, they are the same to us. We have our own programs that don't need high oil prices."This is not how the rest of the OPEC and non OPEC members feel at all – so by nixing any deal he has protected the Saudi's mkt share, and has secured their role as a 'leader' while at the same time laying the groundwork for continued political instability in the region.OK - back to the mkts.....After the initial concerns over these recent developments – the focus returned to US earnings…the day started off with better numbers from Pepsico (PEP), Hasbro (HAS), JB Hunt (JBHT) and in a another surprise move – we learned that Morgan Stanley (MS) – while reporting horrible numbers did in fact "beat all the estimates." Net Income FELL 54%, Equity trading revenues FELL 34%, Fixed Income trading revenues FELL 52% and Investment Banking Revenues FELL 15% - but yet they somehow managed to beat the 'much lower' EPS expectation….so all this means is that we must watch out for Goldman Sachs (GS) report this morning.....Analysts expect EPS of $2.48......Now remember – Uncle Lloyd pre-announced this 're-structuring' plan late on Friday – so investors/traders have been prepped about all the bad news and how he has dealt with it head on…. – and like Cousin Jamie (Dimon) of JP Morgan (JPM)– Uncle Lloyd knows how to 'massage' the street analysts – so what I expect to hear this morning is a 'BLOW YOUR SOCKS OFF EPS' beat to rival even the most generous estimate….and the clock ticks towards 7:30 am......In other news - United Health (UNH) just reported a better number - $1.81 vs. exp of $1.72, Philip Morris (PM) on the other hand missed - $0.98 vs. exp of $1.10..... Watch for Brinker (EAT), Comerica (CMA), Genuine Parts (GPC), Harley Davidson (HDI), Kansas City Southern (KSU),Johnson & Johnson (JNJ).Take Good Care
